Hi Jim - 

Interesting to read more about these terms. Going back again to =
the very minute-sized shakudo dragon menuki that received "Kyo-kanagushi" i=
n Chicago. What had me thinking they might be, shall I say...higher quality=
 (?)...was the use of gold utori on the (male's) tail and the wiskers. It s=
urprised me to think they (Kyo-kanagushi/late Edo anybody) did utori work. =
Utori overlay always makes me think Momoyama. Anything worth expanding on h=
ere? Just curious.  

Ron
STL

  From: Richa=
rd Turner

  Excellent JIm, an=
other lesson learnt, I will store that away for future 
  reference.

  Tha=
nks again

  Rich

  Jim Gilbert wrote:

  > Rich,
  > Kyo kanagu shi is =
=E4=BA=AC Kyoto =E9=87=91=E5=85=B7 metal fittings =E5=B8=A5 maker.  (Althou=
gh 
  > dictionary definitions of this shi kanji are more like master or 
 =
 > commander, I haven't seen it translated that way for this compound 
  > =
term.)  I have seen it used as an attribution on both NTHK and NBTHK 
  > o=
rigami. 
  >
  > The meaning sounds rather similar to Kyo Kinko (=E4=BA=AC=
=E9=87=91=E5=B7=A5), or Kyoto 
  > metalsmith, but in practice usually desi=
gnates somewhat lower quality 
  > work.  A lot of mumei Edo period kozuka =
and kogai made in Goto style, 
  > but not actually Goto work, will get an =
attribution to Kyo Kinko.  
  > Something that deviates further from Goto s=
tyle and is a bit lower 
  > quality will be called Kyo Kanagushi.  That's =
not an exhaustive 
  > definition, but I hope it gives you some idea. 
  >
=
  > A lot of Edo period kinko material isn't distinctive enough to allow 
 =
 > an attribution to an individual or even a group.  For another example, 
=
  > a lot of later, average, unsigned menuki will be attributed to Kyo 
  >=
 Kanagushi.  It's not necessarily bad stuff, but there's no way to 
  > ide=
ntify it further.
  >
  > Your kozuka is probably borderline for passing du=
e to the quality and 
  > condition being a bit rough, but if it did, the a=
ttribution would 
  > likely be Kyo kanagu shi based on what I've observed.=

  >
  > Jim
  >
  >
